summary.seg: Compilations of recipes - often referred to as 'receptaria' - survive in great numbers from the late medieval period. This is one of several examples among the manuscript collections of Cambridge University Library. It was made around the late 14th or early 15th century and contains over two hundred separate medical recipes, as well as several performative rituals or charms that were likewise designed to heal the sick or aid someone at a time of distress. The recipes begin with a rubric or title, which describes the illness that it will treat. They are almost all written in Middle English, bearing witness to the circulation of medical knowledge in the vernacular language of the day. Some of the charms, and the occasional rubric, are written in Latin, suggesting that some degree of literacy in that language was expected as well.

Recipes in such compilations are commonly arranged in approximate head-to-toe order. The first in this manuscript deal with headache, cleansing of the head, 'vanity' of the head (i.e. dizziness), 'evil hearing' (i.e. deafness), clearing the sight or red eyes, watering eyes and so forth (f. 1v onwards). They continue down through the body, addressing aching or swelling in the legs and feet, shingles and 'wildefer' (i.e. erysipelas) (ff. 8v-9r). However, there then follows a series of miscellaneous recipes, covering everything from fevers and snake-bites to gout and sores, before starting again with problems of the head: 'þe web in þe ye' (i.e. a film or cataract on the eye), head ache, swelling or scalding of the head and so on, before moving on to other parts of the body (f. 17r onwards). Treatments for specifically female ailments are common throughout and are not placed separately. They include cures for aching in the womb and the 'menisoun' (period pain and bleeding, ff. 6r-6v), soreness in the breast (ff. 42v, 46r) and swelling in the womb (f. 46v). There is also a charm 'for womman þat trauaileth of child' (i.e. having a difficult labour), which invokes the names of important female saints and their saintly children: St Mary, who bore Christ; St Anna, who bore Mary; St Elizabeth, who bore St John the Baptist; St Cecilia, who bore St Remigius, and so on (ff. 49r-50r). These are known as 'peperit' charms, from the third person past tense form of the Latin verb 'parere', 'to give birth to'.

As many of these examples show, a large part of the contents of this manuscript is concerned with mundane ailments. Some of the remedies are also cosmetic, attesting to a desire to improve one's appearance: how to get rid of freckles (which could be misinterpreted as signs of a disease) (f. 17v), to whiten one's teeth (f. 26r) or face (f. 13v), or solve bad breath (ff. 26r-26v). The recipes mention common household ingredients such as milk, honey, wine or vinegar and animal fats, herbs such as rue, tansy, fennel, sage or rosemary, and plants such as speedwell, hollyhock or betony. The preparatory techniques are simple, often involving stamping, beating, mixing, tempering and boiling the ingredients together, which processes would require the same basic household equipment used for cooking. More serious illnesses or injuries are also mentioned, with treatments for rankled wounds (ff. 44v, 81v), canker on a woman's breast (f. 46r), bleeding (f. 86v), dysentery (f. 32v) and broken bones (f. 73r) providing vivid, sometimes visceral, reminders of the pain and precarity of medieval life. There are also a few diagnostic guides, to determine whether a skull has been fractured or not (f. 41r), to find out where canker breeds (f. 51r), or to know whether a wounded or a sick man shall live or die (ff. 43r-43v). The recipes often conclude with claims as to their efficacy with formulaic statements, such as 'Thou schalt be hool' (i.e. whole / well; ff. 2r, 4r, 6r, etc), 'on warantise' (i.e. guaranteed; ff. 17r, 78r, 82v), 'probatum est' (i.e. proven; f. 37v). Occasionally, medical authorities are invoked: 'a drink for al maner feueres or postumes (i.e. abscesses) or what siknesse is within þe body' is attributed to 'ypocras philosophus' (i.e. Hippocrates; ff. 28r-29r). Towards the end, there are clustered together three recipes for 'gracia dei' with endorsements by more recent figures: 'lady behamp þe erles wif of warwik' (f. 78v), 'þe good Erl of herford...þat was holde a noble surgien' (f. 79v) and someone by the name of 'obkyn fermory of knesworth' (f. 80v). Kneesworth is a village north of Royston in Hertfordshire. Comprison with other, similar compilations indicates that the copyist of this manuscript misread his exemplar (or was working from a faulty one): in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.1.13, f. 58v, the rubric instead attributes the recipe to 'hopkyn of þe fermorye of kenelworth' (i.e. the infirmary in Kenilworth, a town in Warwickshire).

As other examples from the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project illustrate, receptaria manuscripts often bear the signs of home-made production, suggesting copying and compilation by medical practitioners themselves (see, for example, Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 9309). MS Add. 9308, meanwhile, offers a noteworthy contrast. Its layout is uniform, with a writing frame and sixteen lines ruled neatly on each page; the text is written by a practised hand in a consistent semi-formal Anglicana formata script; and the rubrics are neatly underlined in red ink. There are decorative flourishes too: initials painted in blue at the beginning of each recipe, including two larger ones at the start that are accompanied by marginal pen-flourishing and infill in red ink of a sort typical in late medieval manuscripts. All in all, the material evidence points to this manuscript being a professional production. Textual evidence may be adduced to suggest further that it was made not necessarily in response to a specific commission, but was one of multiple copies made speculatively for sale to potential customers, as a compendium of all of the useful household medical knowledge that one could need. Before the recipes begin, the scribe has copied a short poem, which introduces the contents of the book to its reader and explains its usefulness, much like a modern-day publisher's 'blurb':

Þe man þat wele of lechecraft lere
Rede ouer þis bok and he may here
Many a medicyn boþ good and trewe
to hele sores boþ olde and newe
Heryn arn medicines withoute fable
To hele alle sores þat arn curable
Of swerd knif and of arue
Be þe wounde wyd or narue
Of spere of quarel of dagger of dart
to make him hol in eche part...

Nothing is known of the origins of the manuscript, however, and the date of its production can only be an estimated based on the style of handwriting. At a very early stage, perhaps before the manuscript was first bound, a quire of six leaves was added to the beginning, onto to which another, less neat hand began to insert of a table of contents. This scribe copied out the rubrics for each recipe, bracketing them together where they occurred on the same leaf, and keying these to the folio numbers he added to the leaves in the main part of the manuscript. Such apparatus initially developed in earlier centuries and primarily in texts for formal study. This addition to MS Add. 9308 illustrates not only that they had spread by the fifteenth century to manuscripts produced for wider consumption, but also that their function and use was intuitive to late-medieval readers who desired ready-reference access to the contents of their books. The manuscript also points not only to widening literacy in lay society, but also to a growing appetite for access to medical knowledge - a demand mediated by the commercial production of small, portable, affordable (though not necessarily cheap) books, whose contents were written primarily in the vernacular, and aimed primarily at readers without formal medical training, who were nevertheless aware of and wished to understand and treat illness.

The leaves that were left blank at the time of production were nonetheless ruled and ready for copying, whether for the completion of the table of contents at the beginning or perhaps the addition of further remedies at the end. Many of these were were later filled with scribbles and pen-trials - among which is an inscription by a 16th-century hand that attests to the early ownership of the manuscript: 'Thys ys thomas hullis boke of stebbyng' (f. i recto; the same name is repeated on f. iv recto). Stebbing is a village in Essex, and the Hull family was of longstanding there during the 15th and 16th centuries, with numerous Thomas Hulls are attested in manorial and other records. One is mentioned in a court record of 1538 as the owner of property in the village's main street, with further occurrences in the records in subsequent years. A will in the name of Thomas Hull, mercer, is dated 1558, and also mentions a son by the same name. The son may be the Thomas recorded in court records of 1584 as 'recently deceased'; again, his son is named Thomas. One or other of these may have been the owner, however it may be that the 'Thomas Hull of Stebbing' who inscribed MS Add. 9308 is also the signatory 'Thomas Hull the elder' of an indenture of a lease from 1553 (now Essex Record Office, D/DVx/6). Not only is the style of handwriting in both closely similar, but also Thomas Hull is styled in the lease as 'Thomas Hull the elder, barbour' - a title commonly applied at this time to practitioners of medicine and minor surgery. (My thanks to Professor Lawrence Poos of the Catholic University of America and to Graham Jolliffe of Stebbing Local History Society for this information).

Dr James Freeman
Medieval Manuscripts Specialist
Cambridge University Library

Numbering in ink in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos, by a 16th-century hand.

collation.p:
The manuscript comprises 13 quires, mainly of 8 leaves. The first quire is of separate though near-contemporary production. Disruption to the text suggests the loss of a quire after Quire 12, though it is unclear whether or not Quire 13 was of separate production or merely reflect a change in scribal hand.
Quire 16 (ff. i-vi)
Quires 2-118 (ff. 1-80)
Quire 124 (ff. 81-84)
Quire 136 (ff. 85-90)

note.p: Modern quire signatures - †, a-m - have been added in pencil to the lower right-hand corner of the recto of the first leaf of each quire, by J.S. Ringrose Ringrose, J.S. (Jayne S.), as part of the cataloguing of the manuscript, c. 2019.

A piece of paper pasted inside the front cover: 'Written in the reign of Henry VI that is, at the beginning of the 15th century. Compare Astle origin of Writing Tab. XXVII.14'. Upside down at the foot of this: 'This was the Lady Bechamp the Erles wife of Warwick [...] and 77 when she lived'.

binding.p: 17th- or 18th-century pasteboards, covered in brown leather. Blind-tooled panel in double fillet on both. At the time of writing (September 2023), the front and rear board are both detached, with remains of the spine attached to the rear board. The manuscript will be rebound as part of the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project.

history.provenance: 'Thys ys thomas hullis boke of stebbyng' (f. i recto; repeated in part on f. iv recto): Stebbing is a village in Essex and numerous Thomas Hulls are attested in manorial and other records relating to it. One or other of these may have been the owner, however it may be that the 'Thomas Hull of Stebbing' who inscribed MS Add. 9308 is also the signatory 'Thomas Hull the elder' of an indenture of a lease from 1553 (now Essex Record Office, D/DVx/6). Not only is the style of handwriting in both closely similar, but also Thomas Hull is styled in the lease as 'Thomas Hull the elder, barbour' - a title commonly applied at this time to practitioners of medicine and minor surgery.
'5.5.0': unidentified ?pressmark (probably not a price, if £5 5s, perhaps if 5s 5d), though it is possible the annotation may be unrelated to the manuscript.
history.acquisition: Acquired by Cambridge University Library at Bonham's, 23 May 1995, lot 202.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msItem.title: Table of contents (incomplete)
msItem.rubric: i verso This is þe calender of þe medecynes in þis book wreten
msItem.incipit: i verso For þe heued ache
msItem.explicit: iii recto For to make þe face whiȝt
msItem.note: Added on a separate quire and copied by a different but closely contemporary hand to the main text. Recipes are grouped together by numbered braces, which relate to contemporary foliation in the main text.

collation.p:
A single quire of six leaves, apparently added to the volume after the initial phase of copying of the recipes in Part 2.
Quire 16 (ff. i-vi)

supportDesc.condition: Stains to ff. i recto-ii recto. Offset on f. ii verso from scribbles/pen-trials on f. iii recto. Scribbles/pen-trials and much smudging on the rest of the leaves.

p.seg: Ruled in ink, frame and line, single column (occasionally with one line running over to the next, or two headings written on one line). 16 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in Anglicana formata, perhaps by two hands (changing over on f. ii verso, at 'For to do a norsche haue melk').

note.p: Correction of text through erasure and overwriting on last line of f. ii recto.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 9308, ff. 1-90
msIdentifier.msName: Part 2: Compilation of medical recipes and charms

msItem.title: The man that will of leechcraft lere
msItem.incipit: 1r Þe man þat wele of lechecraft lere / Read ouer þis bok and he may here
msItem.explicit: 1v He schal be hol boþ flesch and bon
msItem.note: Attested in 24 manuscript witnesses, including this one, though not always presented as an introduction at the beginning of a head-to-toe compilation of medical recipes and charms.

msItem.title: Collection of c. 265 medical recipes and charms
msItem.note: Written principally in Middle English, but with some rubrics and charms written in Latin.
Includes a charm written in Middle English verse (not in DIMEV).

msItem.title: Two recipes
msItem.note: 'To make vergres' (i.e. verdigris) and a cure for farsy for a horse.
Added by two separate, later hands, of 16th and 17th centuries.

collation.p:
Twelve quires of mostly eight leaves, ending with two quires comprising four and six leaves each. Disruption to the text suggests the loss of a quire after Quire 12, though it is unclear whether or not Quire 13 was of separate production or merely reflect a change in scribal hand.
Quires 2-118 (ff. 1-80)
Quire 124 (ff. 81-84)
Quire 136 (ff. 85-90)

signatures.p: Leaf signatures in the usual late medieval form, beginning a i-iiii but most cropped partly or entirely.

supportDesc.condition: Smudging of text on f. 9r. Staining to varying degrees on leaves throughout the volume. Scribbles/pen-trials on the closing leaves and especially heavy staining on f. 90v

p.seg: Ruled in ink, frame and line, single column. 16 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in Anglicana formata, for the most part by a single hand, with a change of hands apparently occurring on f. 85r and again on f. 88r.

note.p: Deletion of text by strikethrough: see, for example, ff. 3v, 7r, 12v. Marginal or interlinear insertion of missing words by medieval hands: see, for example, ff. 14r, 21r, 22r, 28r. Correction of text by erasure and over-writing by a later hand on f. 13v. Correction by expunction and insertion on f. 17v.

Þe man þat wele of lechecraft lere
Rede ouer þis bok and he may here
Many a medicyn boþ good and trewe
to hele sores boþ olde and newe
Heryn arn medicines withoute fable
To hele alle sores þat arn curable
Of swerd knif and of arue
Be þe wounde wyd or narue
Of spere of quarel of dagger of dart
to make him hol in eche part
So þat þe sike wele do wisely
And kep hymself from surfetry
Be þe wounde neuer so deep
þerof thar hym take no keep
So þat he drinke saue of antioche
him þar noȝt drede of þat outrage

Be þat on and twenti days ben come and gon
He schal be hol boþ flesch and bon
For heued ache . Sethe verueyne
beteyne and wermod and þerwith
wasch þy hed and þan mak a plastre
þus and ley it on þy molde . Tak þe
same herbes whan þey be sothe and
wryng hem and grynd hem smal in
a morter and tempere hem with þe same
licour and do þerto whete bren for to
holde in þe licour and mak a garlond
of a keuerchef and bynde þerwith þyn
heued and lay þe plastre on þe molde
withynne þe garlounde as hoot as
þou miȝt suffre and bynd þyn heued
with a voluper and set a cappe aboue

and do þus thries and þou schalt be hool .
For clenseng of þe heued . tak
peletre of spayne and chewe þe rote
þre dayes a good quantite and it schal
purge þyn heued and do awey ache
and faste þy teth. For vanite of
þyn heued . tak ious of walwort
and salt and hony and wex and encense and
boile hem to gedere and þerwith anoyn
te þy heued and þy temples . For
euel heryng tak grene plantes
of asch and bren hem and kepe þe water
þat cometh out at þe endes a schelle-
ful and þe ious of sengrene thre
schelleful and a schellful of elys
grees and of þe ious of þe nether

ende of lekes a schelleful and a schelle
ful of hony and medele hem to gedere
and boile hem a litil to gedere and do
hem in a viole of glas and put þerof
in þy hool here and ligge dounward
with þe deef here and þou schalt be hol
with inne .ix. tymes and take þe
wolle of a blak schep pulled from
vnder þe wombe and wete þerin and
ley it aboue . Also . take gres of
an el and ious of sengrene of ech
a lich and medele hem to gedere and
a litil boile hem and do it in þyn
hool here as it before seyd .
For to clere þe siȝte . and for reede
eyen . Rubbe whit gynger on a

weston in a fayr bacyn and tak as
miche salt as þou hast poudre and
grinde hem wel to gedere in þe
bacyn . and tempere hem with whit wyn
and let it stonde a day and a nyȝt
and þan tak þe þinne þat standeth
a boue and do it in to a viole of
glas and whan þou gost to bedde
wete a fethere þerin . and anoynte
þy eyen . For watering eyen .
Anoynte a reed cool lef with þe
white of an ey and ley to þyn eyen
whan þou gost to bedde . For to
sle wermes þat ete þe eyeliddes .
tak salt and brenne it in a clout
and tempere it with hony . and with a fethere

anoynte þy eyeliddes whan þou gost
to bedde For soor eyen . or soor
mowth .tak eufras a good quantite

þorw a cloth and tak bores gres or

gres and medele hem wel to gedere in
a bras panne and boile hem wel and stere

a litil þer of in þyn eyen For sor

foile a good quantite and staumpe it
and boile it in fair water and whan
it is boiled hold ope þyn mouth
þer ouer and lete þe eir þerof in to þy

throte as hoot as þou miȝt suffre

it kelith in þy mouth spat it out
and tak fresch . and do so thries o .iiii.
times and þou schalt be hool .
For him þat hath lost his speche .
Do þe ious of sauge or of primerol
in his mouth and he schal speke .
For him þat spateth blood . tempere
þe ious of beteyne with gotis melk
and do him drinke þerof .iii. dayes .
Also . tak smalache and mynte and
rue and beteyne and boile hem wel in
god melk and soupe it warm .
For a purgacioun . tempere poudre

of laureol with hony . ech a lich miche .
For stingeng breth þorw þe nose .

eng til and mak a pipe of latoun

seid thinges schal sle þe wermes

rynwode with wyn and drink þerof
what þou gost to bedde . For to
mak a man to haue talent to mete

þe stomak and þe brest ¶ For almaner

hem wel to gedere and drink þat pouder

þe stomak . tak fenel rote and ache
rote . a lich . and staumpe hem to gedere

For thurst . staumpe þe rote of
loueache and tempere it with water and drink

For þe coughe . tak sauge and

at euen . and an oþer at morwen .
For þe chinke . tak þe rote of
horselue and rote of coumfery . a lich .

and grind hem smal in a morter and seth

sumed and tak two del þerof and þe

hem to gedere and mak a letuarye
þer of and do it in a box . and vse þerof .v.

ones first and last and þou schalt be hol .
For akyng in þe wombe . staump
fiueleef and tempere it with stal ale .
and let þe sike drynk þer of iii. spon-
ful at ones and bynd puliol sothe
to his nauele as hot as he may
suffre . Also . Staump rue with
salt an tempere it with ale or water
and drink it . For þe menisoun .

with þe ious of ꝫarwe and of weybred

and mak a plastre þerof and ley it to
þy bak as hote as þou miꝫt suffre .
For wermes in þy wombe .
Staump nepte and tempere it with hoot
wyn . and drink whan þou felest þe
wermes greue þe . For costif-
nesse Sethe malues and mercurye
with a mes of pork and mak þer of

potage and ete wel þerof . and drink
whit wyn or whey For þe flix .
tak hennecressen and croppes of
wodebynde þat berith honysukkeles
and staump hem and tempere hem with
warm red wyn . and drink þerof . and
ete thre dayes ferst . v fyue lekes
with therf bred þat is hot . and drink
no drynk but red wyn warm
and haue þou a stol with a sege and mak
þer vndir a litil charcol fer and sit þou
on þe stol bare a good while
and þou schat be hol . but lok þi clo-
thes go to grounde and kepe in þe
hete þat it mow passe vp in to þy
fundament For ache in þe lendes .

Staump weybrode and sanicle and do
þer to bores gres and mak a plastre
and ley þer to wel warm For þe ston .
tak gromyl and parcil and red nettele
and violet and ache and cheriston ker-
neles . and staump þe kerneles by
hem self in a brasyn morter and þe er-
bes in a stonen morter and þan do
hem in a pot of erthe and do þerto
whit wyn and seth it ouer þe fer
and so lat it stonde in þe same ves-
sel and drink þer of warm and þou schat
be hol . For pissing of blood .
tak amorose on handful and san-
guinarie as mich . and parcely seed
half on handful and staump hem and

tempere hem with gotis melk and drink
þerof For him þat may noȝt wel pisse .
Staump rue and gromyl and parcil . and tem-
pere hem with whit wyn and do hym
drinke warm . For swolle
ballokes and sore . tak pouder of
comyn and barly mele and hony and
fry hem to gedere and mak a plastre
and bynd it aboute þe sor ballok
riȝt warm For scalded pyntil
or apegalle . tak lynen cloth þat
is clene wasche and bren it and mak
þer of poudre and tak oyle of eyren
and anoynte þe sor and put þe pouder
in þe
sor
holes For akeng or
swelleng in thies or in feet

Sethe rote of walwort in water
and do awey þe ouerest rynde and tak
þe middele and staump it and do þerto
bores gres and mak a plastre and ley
þerto as hot as þou miȝt suffre .
For akyng or swelleng of
legges and feet . Staump mugwort
and do þerto barues gres and frye it
to gedere and mak a plastre and
ley þer to. Also bete comyn to
pouder and do þer to barues gres and
frye oyle dolif and frye hem togedere
and mak a plastre and ley þer to .
For þe sengles . þer is an euel þat
men calle þe sengles and is red in
þe maner of wildefer and it wele

springe in þe maner of wildefer
on a roue . and ȝif it beclippe a
man he schal be ded þer of . and þerfor .
tak dowis drit þat is moist
and barly mele of ech half a pound
and staumpe hem wel to gedere and do
þer to half a pynte of good vyn
egre and medele hem wel to gedere
and ley it cold to þe sor . and ley wor-
te leues aboue for to holde in
þe licour and bynd a cloth al aboue
and let it lye thre dayes and þan re-
fresch it with newe and he schal be
hol withinne thre plastres For
wildefer . tak wyn drestes or
drestes of vynegre and an ey bothe

þe white and þe ȝelke by euene
mesure and tempere hem wel to gedere
and ley þer to til it be hol For þe
dreye cowghe . tak anys and seed
of ache and sed of violet . alich .
and bete hem to pouder and tempere hem
with wyn and seth hem wel to-
gedere til it be thikke . and do it
in boistes and vse þerof ferst and last
For þe morsew whit or blak .
tak an vnce of verdegres and anoþer
of quik brumston and mak of bothe
pouder as smal as þou miȝt and tak
two schepis heuedes þat be fatte
and clene hem and tak out þe brayn .
þan wasch hem clene and sethe hem

til þey be tendre þan tak doun
þe vessel and let kele . and gadere
þe gres and tempere it with þe poudres
and mak an oynement þer of . but
lat it come ny no fer for it
must be wrouȝte al cold . and
anoynte þe sike þerwith .
Also . tak ius of celidoyne and
medele it with poudre of brum-
ston . and do to þe morfew alcold .
For swot . staump linsed and
letuse to gedere and ley to þi
stomak and vse it til þou be hol .
For þe iawnes . Seth wermod
in water and wasche þe þerin riȝt
wel twyes or thries and drink

yuory schauen in wyn . Also . tak
celidoyne a pound and a quartroun of
licorys and a galoun of water . and
schaue þe licoris and brose it wel
and put it and þe celidoine in to þe
pot and lat sethe from a galoun to
a potel and drink þerof For to
do a norsche haue melk . tak
verueyne and drink with wyn . or
fenel and ete letuse and botere and drink
fenel seed with wyn . Or brek cristal
to poudre and drink it with melk
For to weten ȝif he hath þe
menisoun schal liue or deye . tak
a peny weyȝte of touncressen and
seed and ȝif þe sike to ete and do him

drinke red wyn after or water and
do þus thre dayes and ꝫif he staun
che he may leue with help and ellis
he is ded . For ony werm in
þin ere . tak ious of wormod
or of rue . or of sotherinwode and
do þer in . And þou mow noꝫt
holde þi water tak þe clawes
of a goot and bren hem and mak þerof
pouder . and vse þer of in þin potage
a sponful at ones and þou schat be hol .
For to make god entreet tak
fat bacoun þat is old . and melt it
in a panne and let it stonde til þe
salt be falle to þe ground and
þan por out þe gres in to a clene

vessel and lat kele and tak .iii. pound
of rosin and .i. pound wex and a pound
of þe bacoun gres and a pound of
schepis talu and a quartroun of gum-
me galbanum and put þe gumme in
a litil warm water til it be
molte and tak þan þin rosyn and
brek it on smal peces in to a fair
panne and put þer to þi gres and
brek þe wex and do þer to and kit þe
talu and do þer to and do þe gumme
and all þese in to water and seth hem
ouer þe fir and put þer to a quartroun
of good frankencense and half a
quartroun of mastik and halfapound
of perosin and mak þese thre

on smal pouder in a brasin morter
and cast in to þe panne and let it
boile til al þe thinges be molte
þan tak vii. peny weiꝫte of ver-
degres and grind it on a molour
as smal as þou miꝫt and cast it in
to þe panne . þan stere it faste
a great while and tak it doun of
þe fer and put it in a bagge of
caneuas and swile a bacin cle-
ne with water and let þat is in þe
bagge droppe þerin and with a
peire tonges be clippe þe
bagge and faire threst doun þe
tret and whan it is clene þorw
tak a fethere and do a wey þe

fom a boue clene and so lat stonde
al niꝫt and a morwe tak it out
and kerf it as þou lest For ache
or swelling in þe thies knes .
Staump rue and loueache and mede-
le hem with hony and frye hem to gidere
and ley þe plastre warm to þe sor .
For þe feuere cotidian . tak
fetherfoy and smalache . alich . and
staump hem and tempere hem with water
and streyne hem and drink a good
quantite whan þe accesse comith
on þe and þou schalt be hol within
iii. drinkenges . For biting
of an addere . Staump centory and
tempere it with his owne vreyne

and ꝫif þe sike to drink and it is
as good for best as man .
For þe scabbe . Seth þe rote
of horselue in water til it be nesch
and tak old schepes talu and mede-
le hem wel to gedere in a morter
and do it in a lynen clout and an-
oynte þe sor a ꝫen þe fer .
For all goutes . tak an oule
and pul him and open him as þou woldest
ete him and salt him wel and do him in
an erthen pot and ley a til þer on
and set it in to an hote ouene
whan man sette in dow and whan
þey drawe forth lok whethir
he be y now for to mak pouder

of and elles let stonde til he be
þan bete it to pouder and tempere it
with boris gres and anoynte
þe sor bi þe fer For heued-
ache . Seth rue and fenel wel
in water and wasch þer with þin
heued . and mak a plastre as it
is bifore seid . For goundi yen .
tak arnement and honi and þe white
of an ey and staump hem to gedere
and anoynte þerwith þin yen whan
þou gost to bedde . For to make
þi face whyt tak fresch baru
gres and þe whit of an ey and
staump hem to gedere with a litil
pouder of bayes and anoynte

þerwith þe face For al
man
swelling
Tak gromswele and lemke and chi-
kemete and dayeseys and iubarb and
peti morel and herbe beniꝫt and staump
hem and boile hem wel and as hot as
þou miꝫt suffre ley a plastre þerof
to þi sor For to clense þe brest .
Gadere a good quantite of slou
þat be ripe and grind hem smal in
a morter and do hem in an erthen
pot and fil it ful of newe clensed
ale and wry þi pot and mak an
bole in þe erthe and set it þer in
and wry it a boute and aboue with
erthe an so let it stonde .x. daies
and þan tak it vp and drink þer of

a cupful at onis ferst and last at
morwe cold and at euen hoot .
For þe feueres tak thre oblyes
and in þat on writ . pater est alpha et omega .
and mak a point . and ete þat þe ferst
day . þe secunde day writ on þat
oþer oblye . filius est vita . and mak two
titelis . and ete it . þe thridde day
writ on þe thridde oblie . spiritus sanctus
est remedium . and mak .iii. pointes
and ete it . but þe ferst day or þou
ete þe oblie sey a Pater noster and þe
secund day two and . þe thridde
day thre . with as fele . Aue . and
Credo . For þe slo werm cropen
in to þi body . Staump rue and tempere

it with vrine and drink it and he schal
come out . For þe scabbe . tak
red docke rotes and pimpernol and sca-
bious and sorel deboys and celidoine
and staump hem and tempere hem with may
botre and frie it to gedere and streine
it þorw a cloth in to a clene
vessel and cast þer to a good quantite
of brumston pouder and stere wel
to gedere til it be cold and þerwith
anoynte þe til þou be hol . For
to make a bel to gadere and to
breke . tak galbanum and clense
it bi þe fer and mak þer of a plastre
and ley þer to two dayes or it be
take a wey Also . tak a rosted

onioun and lilie rote and sourdockes
and staump hem and frie hem to gedere
with baru gres and with oile dolif
and mak a plastre as hoot as
þou miȝ suffre . and þat wele ripe
it and breke it and if þe holes of
þe beles be smale mak tentis
of linen cloth and wete hem in a
oynement þat is clept vnguen-
tum viride . and do þe tentis in þe
holes and ley a plastre aboue
of diaculon or of good entret
Also . tak heyhoue and walwort
and whit malues and brokelemke
and seth hem in water and wasch þe
sor þerin . Also tak sourdokkes

and whit malues and brokelemke and fry
hem in schepis talu and ley a plastre
to þe sor . Also þe croppes of reed
col wel sothe . leid þerto schal
swage it and hele it . For a perle
in þe ye . at þe biginninge . tak
whit ginger and rubbe it on a
weston of northway in whit
wyn and do þe wyn in a peuter
saucer and set þi weston ende
in þe saucer and so rub þi racyn
of ginger of þe weston in to þe
wyn and tak a fethere and with þat licour
wasch þe sor ye . and it schal do
a wey þe perle and saue þe ye .
For þe festre . tak hony and

poudre of verdegres and seth hem
to gedere in an erthen vessel
and to proue whan it is i now . do
a drope with þe sklice on a cold
yren . or ston . and if it be hard
whan it is cold it is y now .
and fille þe wounde of þat salue
twies a day and þat wele hele þe
festre Men clepe þis þe red salue .
For a feloun þat maketh þe
heued to swelle . tak hertes
gres . and hony and barli mele and hey
houe and peti morel and staump hem
and frie hem wel to gidere and ley a
plastre on þi heued as hot as
þou miȝt suffre but seth rue and

fenel in water and þerwith wasch þi heued
or þou ley on þe plastre and vse þis ofte .
An oynement for sore yen . Do
vinegre in a clen bacin and þe ious
of slon and plom aloen and medele
hem wel to gedere and keuere þe vessel
and lat it stond iii. dayes and thre
niȝtes and þan do it in a box and put
þer of in þi sore yen . For þe web
in þi ye . tak galle of an hare and
hony pured of ech alich and mede-
le hem to gidere and with a fethere
ley it on þe web in þin ye and it
schal breke it with in thre niȝtes
and saue þe siȝte on warantise
For heued ache . Boile pouder

of pepir in whit wyn and as hote
as þou miȝt suffre hold þerof in þi
mouth and whan it is ny cold
spat it out and tak newe and so do
til þe ache be awey Also hold
in þe same wyse . southerinwode
sothe in vinegre . For to don
awey frakenes . tak þe blod of
an hare or of a bole and anoynte
þi face þerwith and it schal do hem awey .
For to mak oynement versilium .
tak half
vnce
a pound of litarge and
half a pound of mastik and half
apound of ceruse or of blanc plum
and .i. vnce of caumfre and demi vnce
of calamyn . medele hem

with eurose and take .dim. pound of me
dewex and cut it on smal pecis
and put it in a fair panne and do al þi
thinges þer to and set ouer a charcol
fer and let hem sethe til þey ben alle
wel medeled and alwey stere it
with a stik til it be cold . Þis oyne-
ment is god if þou be scalded on
þi pintel . or with fer on þi body
or on ony of þi membres and for
scalle and for woundes and for many
oþer maladies For to make oyle
roset . tak .demi.libra. of rose floures
þat ben gadered erly in þe dew and
ful sprad and pul of þe croppes
and clip hem with scheres on smale

peces and put hem in a glas and do þer to
of oile dolif þe grenest þat þou miȝt
finde and medele hem wel to gidere
in þe vessel and stop wel þe vessel and
hang it aȝen þe sunne .xx.ti dayes and
þan draw it þoru a caneuas and put
it in to an oþer glas and cast awey þe
groundes . and stop wel þe glas þer may
non eir out and euery day in þe moruen
whan þou schalt hange forth þe pot
stere it wel with a sticke . and stop it
aȝen . Also anoþer makinge of oile
roset . tak of þe oile and of þe roses
alich weiȝte and do hem to gedere in
to a glas and stop it wel and hange
it in a vessel with water al by þe nekke

during two monthes and euery day stere
it onis and stop it aȝen and þan streine
it þorw a caneuas and do a wey þe
groundes and put it in to a vessel of
glas and stop it wel . and þis of colder
kynde þat þan is þat oþer . For almaner
heued ache tak .i. handful of rue
.i. handful of beteyne . anoþer of uer-
ueyne an oþer of wormod . anoþer of
heyhoue anoþer of red fenel . anoþer
of weybrede . anoþer of eldren bark
and wasch clene þe erbes and pile þe
bark þe vtterest rynde awey and
staump hem smal in a morter and .ix.
bayes þerwith and put hem in to an
erthen pot and þer to a potel of good

red wyn and an oþer of stal ale and seth
it til half be wasted and at þe by
gyning put in a quartroun or an vnce
of pouder peper and seth it with þe erbes
þan tak it doun and streyne it and drink
þerof ferst and last vii sponful at
onis a morue cold at euen hoot
ix daies and wasch þi heued with
þis licour . tak rue heyhoue be
teyne verueyne minte hilwort
red fenel wormod southerinwode
of ech an handful and wasch hem
clene and schrede hem and seth hem
in an erthen pot in fair water and
and wasch þin heuen in þat licour and
schaf þi molde and do forþermor with

þese erbes al as it seyd in þe ferst
medicyn of þis bok . but þis vse
.v. times and renue þi plastre but
onis in þe niȝt and þe day . For þi
molde if it be doun . tak leues of
egrimoine a god quantite and wasch
hem and grind hem and do þerto a good
quantite of hony and frie hem wel to
gedere and schaf þi hed as fer as þe
plastre schal ligge and do it on as
hot as þou miȝt suffre . Also staump
celidoine with may botere and frye
hem wel to gedere and streyne hem
þoru a cauenas and do it in boxes
for it is god to anoynte with þe
molde þat is doun . For feloun

a boute þe heued tak beteyne and
heyhoue and camamille and egrimoyne
of ech an handful and wasch hem and
staump hem and tak hertis gres and hony .
of ech a quartroun and do þer to barly
mele half a quartroun and frye hem
wel to gedere and schaf þi heued and
ley aboue þe plastre as hot as
þou miȝt suffre . For scalled heuedes .
tak .ii. handful of pedelyoun þat is
noȝt floured and seth it wel in a
potel of strong lye til half be
wasted . and þan do wasch þe scallid
heued in strong pisse . wel hot
and schaf clene of alle þe scalles
þan mak a plastre of pedelyoun

wel hot and ley it on þe heued and so
lat lye a day and a niȝt þan tak it
of and tak rye mele and renninge
water and tempere wel to gedere so it be
thikke . and spred it on a clout þat
wele ouer go þe sor
hed
and legge it þer on
and lat it lye .iii. dayes and iii. niȝtes
or it be renued . þan tak it and wasch
wel þe heued in strong pisse and schaf
it clene and tak red onyouns as
many as wele suffice to mak a
plastre ouer þe sor and boile hem wel
in water and staump hem and tempere hem with ious
of calaminte and tempere hem vp with
hold barue gres pured and vse þis
laste plastre til þe sike be hool .

Also . tak pich and medewex and
rosyn and ech a lich be worth and
melt hem to gedere and medele hem
wel þan pore it in a box and set
þe box in water for clening til
it be cold and wasch þe sor heued
in warm pisse and schaue it clene
and tak a lynen cloth and ley it on
þe heued and tak fair herdes of
flex or of hemp and tose it faire a
brod and ley it a brod on þe clout
til þe clout be helid and þan tak
out sum of þat in þe box and mak
pouder þerof in a brasen morter
and strew on þe herdes aboue
til þa herdes be helid and tak anoþer

clout and ley a boue þat . and bynd
bothe cloutes to gedere þat þe
pouder spil noȝt and so lat ligge
vii dayes or viii . and vse þis til
þe forked heres ben puld vp
and at euery time þat þe clout is re-
meued . wasch þe sik hed in
warm pisse and after schaf it clene
and spar noȝt for bleding and mak
a new cappe as þou dest er and whan
it is no ned to vse þis medicin
mor tak þe gres of retheren
feet whan þey be sothe and blowe
it of þe water þat þey were sothen
in and pure it newe and do it in
a box and þat water anoynte þe heued
cappe

til it be hol . A charm for þe hawe
in þe ye . In nomine + patris + et filii
+ et spiritus sancti + amen . y coniure þe
hawe in þe name of þe fader and of þe
sone and of þe holy gost þat fro þis
time foreward þou neuer greue more
þe ye of þis man .N. + ihesu + crist
if it be þi wil draw out þis hawe
and clense þe ye of N þi seruaunt as
verilich and as sothlich as þou clensedest
þe ye of tobie + agios + agios
+ agios + sanctus + sanitus + sanctus
+ christus vincit + christus regnat + christus
imperat + christus sine fine viuit et regnat
In nomine patris etc. Þis charm schal
be seid thries ouer þe ye and at ech

time a pater noster and an Aue writ
þis charm in a scrowe and bere it . and
use þat medecyn þat is a fore write
for þe perle in þe ye . and also þe ious
of celidonie is god to put
in
þe ye
for þe hawe . For sore yen . tak
a quart of good whit wyn and do it
in to a clene masseling panne and þerto
.i. vnce of pouder of sal gemme and boile
hem to gedere a litil and tak hem doun of
þe fer and set it in horsdung and hele
þe panne and ouersprede it with hors-
dung and lat stonde .iii. dayes and
iii. niȝtes and þan tak it out of þe
dunge and pore out of þe clerest in to
a vessel þoru a lynen cloth and do it

in to a viol of glas and with a fethere
do þerof in þin yen whan þu gost to
bedde . For yen þat swellin . tak
þe whit of an ey and þe ious of sengre-
ne and eurose and hony of ech alich
weiȝte and tempere heme wel togedere in
a peuter vessel and tak fair flex and
wete þerin and ley it to þin yen whan
þu gost to bedde . bind it softlich
þerto . And on dayes do þis medi-
cin to þin yen . yak totye . and do
fair water in a peuter saucer and tak
a wheston and set þat on ende in þe
saucer and rubbe þe whiter side
of þe totie on þe westoin doun
in to þe water til þe water be whit

of þe totie and of þat licour put in þin
yen ech day viii times or .ix.
For to make water for yen þat
seme clere and ben blynde . Tak
smalache red fenel . rue . verueyn
beteyn . egrimoyne . sink foil . pimper
nole . eufras sauge celidoine . of
ech a quartroun wasch hem clene and
staump hem and tak þe poudre of .xv.
peper cornes and apinte of good
whit wyn and do to þe erbes . and .iii.
sponful of hony and .v. sponful
of a childes vrine þat is innocent
and medele hem wel to gedere and boile
it al ouer þe fer a litil and streyne
it þoru a clene cloth and do it in

a glas and stop it wel and if it drye
tempere it with whit wyn and with a feþere
do it in þin yen . and it is god for
almaner sore yen and for to make
him se and he schal se within .xv. dayes
Also an oþer water to clere þe siȝte
and to do awey þe perle or þe hawe .
Tak redrose smalache rue ver-
ueyn maidenher eufras endiue
sengrene hilwort redfenel celi-
doine of ech .demi. quarter and wasch hem
clene and ley hem in good whit wyn
a day and a niȝt and after stille hem in
a stillatorie . and þe ferst water
wele be lich gold . þe secund . siluer
þe thrid . lich bawme and kep þat in

a viol . for it is worth baume
for ony maladie of þe eyen .
For toth ache tak peletere of
spayne boþe rote and crop wasch
it and staump it and mak thre balles
in þin hand þerof as grete as a
plumme and ley þe ferst bal bitwen
þe cheke and þe toth þat aketh a
milewey and euer as þe water ga
dereth in to þi mouth spat it
out and whan it hath be þerin so
longe tak out þat and put in a newe
and do as þou dest ferst and so bi þe
thridde and tak a slep after and hele
þe warme and þou schat be hol be þat
þou . hast slept A charm for tothache

Dominus noster + ihesus . christi . supra petram mar-
moream sedebat . petrus tristis ante
ihesum stabat et dixit ei + ihesus . quare
tristis es . petrus respondit dolore dentes

te migranea gutta maledicta per
patrem et filium et spiritum sanctum et per xii.
apostolos et iiii. euangelistas + Mar-
cum + matheum + lucam + Iohannem
et per centum xliiii. milia innocentes
et per mariam matrem domini nostri ihesu christi
que talem filium portauit per quem totus

tem in istum hominem .N. nec in capite nec
in ullo loco corporis sui nocere vale-
as adiuro te per illum qui passus est pro

nobis in cruce amen . For to make
white teth tak reye flour . salt and
hony and medele hem togedere and þerwith
rub þi teth ech day twies or thries
and after wasch hem clene with fair
water . Also tak grene braunches
of brom and bren hem and mak þer of
pouder and do þerto pouder of brent
alum þe fourthe part and medele hem
wel to gedere and tempere hem with water
and rub þerwith þi teth . For stinkeng
breth þat cometh fro þe stomak
Bete .ij. handful of comyn in
a brasen morter to pouder and seth it
in good win from a potel to a quart
and drink it ferst and last as hote

as þou miȝte suffre and drink euery day
a pinte Also . tak hilwort a
good handful and wasch it clene and
kit it smal and do it in a morter and grind
it wel and do þerto .demi. vnce of pouder
peper and .I. vnce of pouder comyn and
do al in a potel of good wyn and
seth it to halues . and vse þis onis
after noon and noȝt a fore and at euen
last alwey hot For stinkenge breth
of þe nosetherlis . tak rue and mynte
of ech alich . of ious . but staump hem
a sunder and medele þe ious to gedere
and lye vpriȝt and do pore þer of in þin
nosetherles þat þe ious mow gon
toward þe brayn . For þe dropesy

in þe wombe and in þe feet and for

þe stomak . and for wermes in þe

iiij. peny weiȝte of scamonye . and
ij. peny weiȝte of rubarbe and vj. pe-
ny weiȝte of cene and iij. peny weiȝte
of pouder water and .demi. peny weiȝte of
cedwal and .j. peny weiȝte of spikenard
and j. peny weiȝte of flour of canel . and

morter . and vse this medicin fastinge
ech day a sponful in. thre dayes and
þou schat be hol . of al þat is foreseid .
For þe migreyin . or for a postem

or for þe dropesy in þe heued and for

weiȝte of peletre of spayne rote
and demi penyweiȝte of spikenard and
grynd hem to gedere and boile hem in good
vynegre . and tak a saucerful of hony
and .v. saucerful of mustard and put
þerto whan it is cold . and þan medele
hem to gedere .
and
vse þerof half aspon-
ful at onys þus . hold it in þi mouth
þe mountaunce of .ij. Credo . and þan

þat þou hast eten . and alitil a fore niȝt
as ofte . and alwey spat it out into

.j. vnce of sugre bete alle to pouder

Forto make a drink for almaner

feueres or postumes or what siknesse
is within þe body . take euery day a

receit afore þat maketh mencioun

ysope . rosmarin . violet . verueine
beteyne . erbe ion . Mousere . rode .
planteyn . Auence . sauge fetherfoy
ache . of ech an handful and wasch
hem clene and do hem in a morter and staump

þat was neuere ocupied and do þerto a ga-

an herseue into a clene vessel . and

wrie and vse þis .ix. dayes at euen
hot a morue cold . and þou schat be
hol . haec ypocras philosophus . For a def man .
Bren grene helm and kep þe water
þat comith out at þe endes a spon-
ful and tak a sponful of sengrene
and a sponful of wyn . and .i. sponful

def here whan he is a bedde but
lok it be warm and he schal be hol
within .ix. daies For þe coughe
tak ysope rosemarin . cerflange
plantayn and rote of radich and
chekelange . of ech a quartroun and seth

hem in wyn from a potel to a quart
þan por out þe licour and do þe erbes

do þe licour in to þe morter and mede-

half a pinte of lif hony yboiled
and a quartroun of may botre pured
and do þerto . and lat hem sethe þe space
of þis psalm . Miserere mei deus
seyenge . þan streyne it þoru a ly-
nen cloth . and put þat licour in a glas
and vse þerof ferst and last ech time
vj. sponful and as miche of stale
ale warmed til he be hol Also .
tak .j. handful of rue . an oþer of

southerinwode anoþer of rosmarin
and a quartroun of pured honi and a quart
of wyn and seth hem to gedere and por
out þe licour and staump þe erbes þan
do þe licour aȝen to hem and boile hem
a litil . þan streyne hem and do þat licour
in a glas and vse þerof a morue cold
and at euen hot . For þe drie cowghe .
tak half a pound of licoris and strap
awey þe rynde and brose it in a morter
and do it in a newe erthen pot and
do þerto a galoun of good wort þat
is noȝt turned . and .i. vnce of sugre
rose wel poudred and a quartroun of
.i. vnce of pouder ginger and a quartroun
of pured honey . and seth hem til half

be wasted þan streyne it and do it in a
clene vessel and vse þerof at euen hot
a morue cold . For þe brest . sethe
ysope in wyn from a potel to a quart
and vse þerof a morue cold at euen hot
til þou be hol . Ȝif þou spate blod for
brosure . tak beteyn verueyn milfoil
and sinkfoil of ech alich and wasch hem
and grind hem in a morter and wring out
þe ious and do þerto as miche gotes
melk and boile hem to gedere wel and soup
þerof .vij. dayes warm in þe wexing
of þe mone and .vij. in þe wanyng and
drink osmund and comfirie .ix. dayes
and þou schat be hol. For wermes
in þe body þat me clepeth lumbrikes

Mak pouder of beteyn and saueyn
ydreyed and drink þerof in hoot
water and as sone as þe poudre is
doun in þe body it wele sle hem and bringe
hem out Also tak sengrene . feþerfoy
and mynte and staump hem and drink þe
ious with warm wyn and it wele
do as þat oþer Also . Drink stancrop
with wermod . For to sle trenchouns
tak fair bacoun and kit it on smale
messes and tak a gret handful of
beteyne and wasch it clene and grind
it smal in a morter and tak a potel of
gotis melk and do þerto þe bacoun
and þe beteyne and seth hem to gedere
til þe bacoun be y now . and ete þat

mete warm and it schal hele þe .
Also tak a saucerful of ious of
calaminte and asmich ious of cento-
rie as mich hony and as mich
vinegre and þe fourthe part of a
sponful of salt and medele þe licours
to gedere and loke þey be riȝt salte
and boile hem alitil ouer þe fer and do it
in a clene vessel and vse þerof fastinge
a saucerful at ones . and as mich
at vnderne . and at noon also but
be þou fastinge til midouer noon þat
day þat þou takest þis medicine .
For þe splen . tak fair barue gres
.ij. pound and .ij. pound asches of aschen
wode and a galoun of rennyng water

and seth hem til it be half wasted þan
streyne it and lat stonde alniȝt and
on þe morue flete of þe gres and
cast awey þe water and melt þe gres
and streyne it eft . and do it in a box . and
þerwith anoynte þe splen . and vse
þis drink . tak rotes of ȝunge
aschen plantes a good quantite and
wormod also and seth hem in wyn from
a galoun to a potel and drink þis a
morue cold and at euen hot . For
þe flix . take a stol with a sege and ley
a gloweng til þervndir . and tak a
quartroun of an vnce of franc encense
poudrid . and ley it on þe til . and sitte
þerouer . and cast clothes aboute þe . þat

þe eir may nowher out but into
þe fundament . and ley anoþer tyl in þe
fer to hete whil þat oþer coldeth and þus
do .iiij. times and ley on ech tyl a quar-
troun of an vnce . of francencense . whan
þis is do . sitte ouer a charcol fer
in þe same wise so it be of an esy
hete . and ete þou of an hot þerf cake
and drink red wyn warm and non oþer
drink and do þus .iij. dayes and þou schalt
be hol . and if þou haue þe blody flix
drink þo .iij. dayes .iij. peny weiȝte
of ȝerdcresse sed and iij peny weiȝte
of hennecresse sed with red wyn . ech day
a peny weiȝte of ech . y medeled to
gedere A charm for þe blody flix .

In nomine + patris + et filii . + et spiritus . sancti . Amen .
Stabat + ihesus contra flumen iordanis
et posuit pedem suum et dixit . Sta aqua
per deum te coniuro . Longinus miles latus
domini nostri ihesu + christi perforauit et continuo
exiuit sanguis et aqua sanguis redemp
cionis et aqua baptismatis . In nomine
patris . restet sanguis . in nomine filij
cesset sanguis In nomine spiritus sancti non
exeat sanguinis gutta ab hoc famulo
dei .N. sicut credimus quod sancta Maria vera
mater est et verum infantem genuit christum .
sic retineant vene que plene sunt sanguinem
sic restet sanguis sicut restabat ior-
danis quando christus in ea baptizatus fuit .
In nomine patris etcaetera . For to staunche

a bleding nose . Bind þi templis with
a liste a boute þin heued þat þe vey-
nes mow noȝt haue here cours and ȝif
l drink þe ious of smalache and ley
vnder þi tonge a paruenke lef and spek
but litil For a costif man . tak
polipodie þat groweth on þe ok
and wasch it clene and grind it smal in
a morter . and tak a god quantite of fair
gres and do þerto . and scalde an old
fat hen . and drawe here and wasch
here clene and stop here with þat po-
lipodie and þat gres . and seth here til
sche be tendre and drink of þat broth
as hote as þou miȝt and tak .iij. grete
oynouns and mak hem holle and fil hem

ful of fresch gres and seth hem in þe
coles til þey be tendre . þan mak
þerof a plastre and bind to þi nauele
and drink whit wyn or whey til þou
be hol For þe squirt . tak on
handful of hennecressen and anoþer
of weybrede and grind hem to gedere
þan frye hem wel with schepes talw
and franc encense and mak a plastre and
ley to þi nauele as hot as þou miȝt
suffre and þou schalt be hol . For þe
emeraudes . Tak a stol with a sege
and do as it is a foreseyd for þe flix
but þou schalt take pouder of mirre
and of encense half on half oþer and if
þou haue grete pappes bynd aboute

hem a red silk thred fast by þe ground
and kerf awey þe pappes aboue þe
thred and thus serue hem alle . and tak
an handful of wormod and wasch
it and staump it and frye it with oile dolif
and mak a plastre and ley þerto as hote
as þou miȝt suffre and anoon go to
bedde . and anoon in þe morue vse
þe forseid sege with þe same pou-
dres . and with in .iij dayes or iiij. þou
schat be hol . but loke þis plastre
be noȝt sterid þo .iij. niȝt or foure .
Also . so þou haue no grete pappes
tak welle cressen and staump hem and
stiue hem in a pot withoute water and
make a plastre and ley to þe emeraudes .

Also . tak litarge of gold and mak
pouder þerof and tempere it with oile violet
and mak a plastre and ley þerto Also .
tak rue and loue ache of ech alich
and grind hem in a morter and medele hem
with hony and frie altogedere and mak a
plastre and ley þerto as hote as þou miȝt
suffre A charm to staunche blod .
Longinus miles latus domini nostri + ihesu
christi lancea perforauit et continuo exiuit
sanguis et aqua in redempcionem nostram .
Adiuro te sanguis pro ipsum + christum .
per latus eius . per sanguinem eius + sta

in flumen iordanis aqua obstipuit
et stetit sic faciat sanguis istius corporis

In + christi nomine et sancti Iohannis baptiste Amen . et
dica ter Pater noster . et ter Aue maria . Also .
ȝif a maister veyne be cut and þe wounde
be large . tak a pece of lene salt
bef þuat wele into þe wounde and rost
it in þe fer til it be thoru hot . and al
hot sp stop it in þe wounde and bind
it fast and it schal staunche anoon and
neuer strene aftir Also ȝif þou se þat
a man be in gret pereil of bledynge
lok wher þe wounde is . ȝif it is
on þe fot . bind him aboue þe ancle
aboute þe leg . and if it be on þe leg
bind him aboue þe kne . aboute þe
thy and if it be on þe hand bind him
aboue þe wrist aboute þe arm

with a liste twyes or thries and it schal
sone staunche . þis medicin is do
for hem þat mow come redely to non
oþer help . A charm for þe same .
Jhesu þat was in bethlem born . and bap-
tised was in flum iordan . and stinted þe
water vpon þe ston stint þe blod
of þis man .N. þi seruaunt . þoru
þe vertu of þin holy name + ihesu
and of þi cosin swete seynt iohn
and sey þis charm .v. times with .v.
Pater noster in þe worschep of þe fiue
woundes Also . tak coperose and saun-
deuer . of ech alich be weite . and bete
hem to poudre and ley it on þe wounde
and staump
smale
þe croppes of rede netles

and do þerto hony and medele hem wel to
gidere and bynd it to þe wounde .
For prikenge of Synewes . tak
oile roset and chaf it and as hote as
þou miȝte suffre por it on þe pricked
place and ley wolle aboue and so bind
it vp and charme it and vse þis til þu
be hol . Forto make a drink for
pestilence . tak fetherfoy and mate-
feloun and mugwort solucle scabi-
solsecle
ouse maithes . of ech alich wasch
hem and staump hem and tempere hem with stale
ale and drink vj. sponful þerof at
onis and if þu haue it betimes
it schal destroye þe corupcioun and
saue þe be þou man or womman .

For bleding at þe nose . Drink
broklemke . smalache and erbe robert
and tempre þe draf with þe white of an ey
and do into his
þi
nosetherles . For a
veyne
nus
cut þoru blod leting . seth
rue in water and staump it and ley it þerto and
tak vnwasche lambes wolle and ley aboue
and it schal be saf For þe ston . tak
gromil mader burnet persil saxifragie
caruy smalache corlage mugwort
diteyne lemke . fenel sed or þe rote
of ech alich and wasch hem and bray hem
and seth hem in stale ale to þe halfdel
þan streyne it and tak poudre of an
hare and a letewarie þat is clept benedicta
of ech a quartroun and do to þat licour and seth

it est riȝtwel and do in a vessel clene
wrie and drink þerof til þou be hol at euen
hot a morue cold Also tak a mal
whit got and fede him iij dayes with
yuy and lat him noȝt drinke but whit
wyn wel salted and at þe thre dayes
ende let him blod bitwen þe clawes
of his feet and whan þe blod is cold
ley it on a fer hot tyl and mak þerof
poudre and drink þerof in warm wyn
probatum est . For swelling of þin
pintil . tak lekes as þey be and wasch
hem and staump hem and frie hem in barue
gres and mak a plastre and ley aboute
þe sor . Also tak ious of weibre-
de and of ribbe and of primerole of ech

alich and do þerto rye flour and frye hem
to gedere and mak a plastre and ley a
boute þe sor . For scalding of þi
pintil . tak .j. handful of erbe robert
of erbe water of bugle of auence
of sanicle of petimorel of sengrene
of pimpernel of hennebane of rednetle
of weibrede of hemp . of orpin of
ech .j. handful . and ribbe and violet
and brembil crop of ech a quartroun and
wasch hem clene and staump hem smale
and do þerto a quart of pured may botere
and staump hem and medele hem wel to
gedere . þan tak a newe erthen
pot and do it þerin and knede it faste
to gedere with þin handes þat it be

noȝt holu and so lat it stonde .ix. dayes
and ix niȝt þan tak it vp and frie it wel
in a panne and streyne it and mak þer of
an oynement and it wele ony malady
of þi pintil or ony wounde þat is cu-
rable . For swelling of þe ballockes .
tempere benemele and vynegre togedere
and mak a plastre and ley þerto .
staump rue and wormod and tak bene-
mele and pouder of comyn . of ech a-
lich and tempere hem with whit wyn and frie
hem alle togedere and mak a plastre and
do it warm þerto . and whan þou takest
awey þe plastre wasch þi ballokes
with warm vinegre For ache in þi
lendes . tak þe rote of smal clote

and wasch it and staump it and tempere it with
stal ale and boile hem wel to gedere
and streyne it and drink þerof at euen
hot amorn cold . For almaner
swelling of legges or feet . tak
welle cressen and schrede hem smale
and do hem in an erthen pot . and do þerto
thikke wyndrestes and whete bren
and schepis talu of ech alich beweiȝte
and seth hem wel to gidere til it be riȝt
thikke . and tak a linen cloth þat wele
sprede þe sor and ley þe plastre þeron
and bind it aboute þe sor as hote as
þou miȝt suffre and stere it noȝt a niȝt
and a day . þan tak it awey and ley þerto
anoþer as þou dest ferst and þou schat be hol .

Forto do awey ache of almaner
strokes or woundes . Bray linsed
in a morter and take as mich wormod
be weiȝte and seth it wel in water . þan
por out þe water and do þe linsed in
þat water and seth it þerin til it be ro-
ping as bridlim . and stamp smale
þe wormod in a morter and do þerto . and
seth hem bothe to gidere þan tak þat and
whete breu and baru gres and frie
hem to gidere and mak a plastre and
ley to þe brosure as hot as þou
miȝt suffre and if it be a wounde
ley a col lef bitwen þat þe gres
go noȝt in . and þis wele sece aking
and withdrawe swellinge .

Also . tak þe rote of holihocke and seth
it til it be tendre and grind it in a morter
and do þerto whete flour and medele hem
wel to gedere with oile dolif . þan frie hem
alle to gedere and as hote as þou miȝt
esely suffre ley to þe sor . Also tak
crummes of whit sour bred wel y
gratid and boile with wyn in a postnet
til it wex thicke as emplastre and al-
wey stere it wel and ley to þe sor as
hote as þou miȝt . For sores þat arn
blo and noȝt broken . tak . ious of
wormod . hony . medewex baru
gres and pouder of comyn of ech alich
weiȝte and frie hem to gedere and mak
a plastre and ley to
þe
sor and þat schal don

and caumfre .iij. vnces . and mirre .ij.
vnces and aloes .ii. vnces and aloes
epatik .viij. vnces and boles galle
half a pynte . tak alle þe for-
seid gummes and staump hem in a
morter and þan put þe galle þerto
and sethe alle to gedere a litil while
ouer þe fer . and þer aftir anoynte
þe place of þe goute with a
fethere whan þou hast it strong
and if þou be an old man tak þe

galle of an old bole . and put
þe forseid oynement . in a
vessel of siluer or tyn or
peuter or latoun . and no bras
ne erthe ne ston .

To make vergires

a ?? of coene sallt and medell
